blocks.text: Preview how an [Article Markdown](/html/other/Article_Markdown.html) would look as a page.
Check out the markdown/styling used in the [Article Editor](/html/other/Article_Editor.html)
The general structure for an element is [<type>Some content here</type>](https://www.w3schools.com/html/html_intro.asp)

<title>Article Markdown</title>
<subtitle>Check out the markdown/styling used in the Article Editor</subtitle>
<superheader>Title, Subtitle, Headers</superheader>
<header>Example Header</header>
<subheader>Example Subheader</subheader>

Beneath a sky painted in fading gold, whispers of forgotten stories danced through the tall grass, weaving memories into the breeze. Shadows stretched like fingers across the earth, and somewhere in the distance, a bell rang for no one, echoing through the stillness like a question never answered.

items: Drinking enough water boosts your energy and concentration.
Regular exercise improves mood and reduces stress.
Reading daily can expand your knowledge and vocabulary.
Getting enough sleep helps your body recover and stay healthy.

A Markdown Table consists of Rows and Columns. A table can contain multiple rows, which contain independent columns. Each Cell is separated by a Pipe Symbol "|". The first cell in a column, which is in the first row is the Title Cell.

Title Cell of Column 1 | Some Value | Another Value
                

                
                Title Cell of Column 2 | Value spreads over entire row
                

                

                

                
                New Row this time
                

                
                And the Columns have changed in width
                

                
                Yet another Value

Title Cell of Column 1 | Some Value | Another Value
                

                
                Title Cell of Column 2 | Value spreads over entire row
Title Cell of Column 1 | Some Value | Another Value
Title Cell of Column 2 | Value spreads over entire row

New Row this time
                

                
                And the Columns have changed in width
                

                
                Yet another Value
And the Columns have changed in width

To create a Table in Markdown, use the <table> element. Then insert as many rows as you want using the <row> element. Columns also need a set column width which has to have a Percent Value.
                For example a column with a width of 50% in markdown is:
Here is the Table from above in Markdown (The spaces are optional)
Title Cell of Column 1 | Some Value | Another Value Title Cell of Column 2 | Value spreads over entire row New Row this time And the Columns have changed in width Yet another Value
An [external Link](https://google.com) (in this case in a header)
<header><link ref="https://google.com">A link</link> (in this case inside of a header)</header>

When linking to another article link only the "location" (eg. the location of [https://cookieCrood.github.io/html/home/Introduction.html](/html/home/Introduction.html) is "/html/home/Introduction.html")

blocks.text: How to contribute, what to contribute and benefits of contributions
Everyone can submit an article for the Documentation in the [Discord](https://discord.gg/qRvcDc3vz5). However, articles must pass verification in order to be added.The verification requirements are:

items: The article is valuable to the Documentation (nothing offtopic)
The article is professional (good grammar, etc.)
The article covers something new (no duplicates, exceptions for Priorities)

blocks.text:
You can contribute anything that is related to Housing.
                    
                    With the exception of:

items: Articles about specific Players
Articles about specific Houses
Articles about specific Events

blocks.text: Articles that cover Priorities are more likely to be verified.
Prioritized article topics can be found in the [Discord](https://discord.gg/qRvcDc3vz5). These are topics that need to be covered as soon as possible.
If your submitted article gets accepted, you will get the following benefits:

items: Credit for the article on the article's page, along with a link to your social media/other
Custom role in the [Discord](https://discord.gg/qRvcDc3vz5), get to preview new Documentation content/features and have a higher chance       of getting your future articles approved
Clout

blocks.text: Change block behavior using Data Values
Data Values are specific values that a block can have in Housing, which changes the blocks behavior when it's placed down. Data Values can be used to create a variety of blocks such as:

items: 6-Sided Logs
Full blocks of a slab (Not double-slabs)
Blocks facing a specific direction

Reformat your texts using Formatting Codes

"Formatting Codes" is a vanilla feature, but is slightly made easier to use in Housing.
As the name suggests, Formatting Codes are used to change the format of text.
(The ones that change texts' color are also known as "Color Codes")
How do I use Formatting Codes?

In Housing, Formatting Codes begin with the ampersand symbol (&).
It is then followed by a certain character to form a Formatting Code.
(Color Codes override other Formatting Codes, so they have to be used before them)

Control player mechanics using Permissions and Groups

Introduced along with Housing, Permissions and Groups is a critical feature used to manage Housings.
Permissions determine what actions a player can perform in a Housing plot, such as building, using items, or interacting with certain mechanics.
Groups are categories that players are assigned to, each with different permission levels.

Why are Permissions important?

Security: Prevents griefing (unauthorized building/destruction).
Organization: Helps manage different types of visitors (e.g., guests, co-owners).
Customization: Allows for roleplay setups (e.g., staff ranks, VIPs).
Automation: Some permissions allow players to bypass certain restrictions (e.g., teleporting, using commands).


Fundamentals
Permissions and Groups is split into multiple functions:

Group Limit
Each Housing has a limit of 20 groups. As of now, it is not possible to extend the limit.

Group Name
Group Name is visible while editing groups, during Action Editing, or when changing groups of other players. It is not visible in normal gameplay.
The maximum length of a group name is 16 characters.

Group Tag
Group Tag is visible in normal gameplay, and is shown as a suffix (after the player's username) on player's nametags.
The maximum length of a group name is 10 characters.
It is also an option to toggle showing the Group Tag in chat.
Group Tags are controlled by Group Color, which is explained below.

Group Color
Group Color pairs along with Group Name and Group Tag. It assigns a color to each group.
There are 16 colors to choose from: Black, Dark Blue, Green, Dark Cyan, Dark Red, Dark Purple, Gold, Gray, Dark Gray, Blue, Lime, Cyan, Red, Light Purple, Yellow, and White.
Different groups can have the same Group Color.

Group Priority
Group Priority, in simpler terms, decides the ranking of each group in the Housing.
Group Priority can be assigned as a number ranged 1 to 20.
More important roles (e.g., admins) should be assigned a higher priority.
This feature is crucial for a lot of usecases, such as assigning priority for Commands and Conditionals.

Set Default Group
Marked as a diamond in the group editing page, it sets a selected group as default.
When players join the Housing for the first time, or joins without a non-default group, they will be assigned with the new default group.
BE CAREFUL! Deleting a group will reset the default group to the group with the lowest priority.

Clear Group Players
Marked as a cauldron in the group editing page, it clears all players from the selected group, including offline players.

Permissions

Permission On // Off Description
Fly On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can fly.
Wood Door On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can open and close wood doors.
Iron Door On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can open and close iron doors.
Wood Trapdoor On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can open and close wood trapdoors.
Iron Trapdoor On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can open and close iron trapdoors WITHOUT REDSTONE.
Fence Gate On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can open and close fence gates.
Button On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can use buttons.
Lever On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can use levers.
Use Launch Pads On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can use Launch Pads (A block similar to Rocket Launch Pads).
/tp On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can teleport.
/tp Other Players On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can teleport other players.
Jukebox On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can use the Jukebox (Background Music Feature for Housings with ranked owners).
Kick a Player On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can kick players off your House.
Ban a Player On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can ban players off your housing.
Mute a Player On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can mute players in your housing.
Chat (Slowmode) On // Slow 1 / 2 / 3 / 5 / 10 / 15 / 30 / 45 / 60s // Off Changes the chat slowmode of players in a certain group, or toggles their ability to chat.
Pet Spawning On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can spawn their Hypixel pets.
Build On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can build in your Housing.
Offline Build On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can build, even when you're offline. This permission requires permission "BUILD" to be enabled.
Fluid On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can place fluids (e.g., water, lava). This permission requires permission "BUILD" to be enabled.
Protools (Worldedit) On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can use Protools. This permission requires permission "BUILD" to be enabled.
Use Chests On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can use chests.
Use Ender Chests On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can use ender chests.
Item Editor On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can use /item to edit items in their inventory. This includes enchantments, item descriptions (lore), and more.
Default Gamemode Adventure // Survival // Creative Changes the default Gamemode of players in a certain group.
Switch Gamemode On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can change their Gamemodes.
Edit Variables On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can use /variables to change values in your Housing system.
Change Player Group On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can change groups of other players. This feature only allows modifying the groups of players in lower priorities.
Change Gamerules On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can change Gamerules in your Housing.
Housing Menu On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can use the Housing Menu.
Team Chat Spy On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can /chatspy to view chat of all teams when Team Chat is enabled.
Edit Actions On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can edit actions in items or systems they have access to.
Edit Regions On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can create, edit and delete Regions.
Edit Scoreboard On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can edit the Scoreboard.
Edit Event Actions On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can create, edit, and delete Event Actions.
Edit Commands On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can create, edit, and delete Commands.
Edit Functions On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can create, edit, and delete Functions.
Edit Inventory Layouts On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can create, edit, and delete Inventory Layouts.
Edit Teams On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can create, edit, and delete Teams.
Edit Custom Menus On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can create, edit, and delete Custom Menus.
View Analytics On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can view analytics about your Housing.
Item: Mailbox On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can place Mailboxes.
Item: Egg Hunt On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can place and remove Egg Hunts eggs.
Item: Teleport Pad On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can place and edit Teleport Pads.
Item: Launch Pad On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can place and edit Launch Pads.
Item: Action Pad On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can place and edit Action Pads.
Item: Hologram On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can place and edit Holograms.
Item: NPCs On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can place and edit NPCs.
Item: Action Button On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can place and edit Action Buttons.
Item: Leaderboard On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can place and edit Leaderboards.
Item: Trash Can On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can place and remove Trash Cans.
Item: Biome Stick On // Off Toggles whether players in a certain group can use Biome Sticks.


Managing Groups
How to Create/Edit/Delete a Group?
To create a group, navigate to: Housing Menu → Permissions and Groups → Create Group (Marked as an Oak Sign)
To edit a group, navigate to: Housing Menu → Permissions and Groups → A group you have currently (Marked as a color-coded player head)
To delete a group, navigate to: Housing Menu → Permissions and Groups → A group you have currently → Delete Group (Marked as a TNT block)
BE CAREFUL! Deleting a group will reset the default group to the group with the lowest priority.

Default Groups in a new Housing
When you create a Housing plot, players are automatically sorted into different groups with preset permissions. These are:

  
    Group
    Tag
    Priority
	Permissions
  
  
    Guest
    [GUEST] (Not visible)
    1
    Fly, Wood Door, Iron Door, Wood Trapdoor, Iron Trapdoor, Fence Gate, Button, Lever, Use Launch Pads, Chat Slowmode 3s, Use Chests, Use Ender Chests, Gamemode Adventure, Housing Menu
  
  
    Resident
    [RESIDENT] (Visible)
    2
    All permissions of Guest, with the following exceptions:/tp, /tp Other Players, Jukebox, Kick, Mute, Chat Slowmode 0s, Pet Spawning
  
  
    Co-Owner
    [CO-OWNER] (Visible)
    3
    All permissions of Resident, with the following exceptions: Ban, Change Player Group
  
  
    Owner
    [OWNER] (Visible)
    100 (Protected Value)
    All permissions

Managing Groups
How to Create/Edit/Delete a Group?
To create a group, navigate to: Housing Menu → Permissions and Groups → Create Group (Marked as an Oak Sign)
To edit a group, navigate to: Housing Menu → Permissions and Groups → A group you have currently (Marked as a color-coded player head)
To delete a group, navigate to: Housing Menu → Permissions and Groups → A group you have currently → Delete Group (Marked as a TNT block)
BE CAREFUL! Deleting a group will reset the default group to the group with the lowest priority.

Default Groups in a new Housing
When you create a Housing plot, players are automatically sorted into different groups with preset permissions. These are:

  
    Group
    Tag
    Priority
	Permissions
  
  
    Guest
    [GUEST] (Not visible)
    1
    Fly, Wood Door, Iron Door, Wood Trapdoor, Iron Trapdoor, Fence Gate, Button, Lever, Use Launch Pads, Chat Slowmode 3s, Use Chests, Use Ender Chests, Gamemode Adventure, Housing Menu
  
  
    Resident
    [RESIDENT] (Visible)
    2
    All permissions of Guest, with the following exceptions:/tp, /tp Other Players, Jukebox, Kick, Mute, Chat Slowmode 0s, Pet Spawning
  
  
    Co-Owner
    [CO-OWNER] (Visible)
    3
    All permissions of Resident, with the following exceptions: Ban, Change Player Group
  
  
    Owner
    [OWNER] (Visible)
    100 (Protected Value)
    All permissions
Organization: Helps manage different types of visitors (e.g., guests, co-owners).
Customization: Allows for roleplay setups (e.g., staff ranks, VIPs).
Automation: Some permissions allow players to bypass certain restrictions (e.g., teleporting, using commands).
Permissions and Groups is split into multiple functions:
Each Housing has a limit of 20 groups. As of now, it is not possible to extend the limit.

Group Name is visible while editing groups, during Action Editing, or when changing groups of other players. It is not visible in normal gameplay.
The maximum length of a group name is 16 characters.

Group Tag is visible in normal gameplay, and is shown as a suffix (after the player's username) on player's nametags.
The maximum length of a group name is 10 characters.
It is also an option to toggle showing the Group Tag in chat.
Group Tags are controlled by Group Color, which is explained below.

Group Color pairs along with Group Name and Group Tag. It assigns a color to each group.
There are 16 colors to choose from: Black, Dark Blue, Green, Dark Cyan, Dark Red, Dark Purple, Gold, Gray, Dark Gray, Blue, Lime, Cyan, Red, Light Purple, Yellow, and White.
Different groups can have the same Group Color.

Group Priority, in simpler terms, decides the ranking of each group in the Housing.
Group Priority can be assigned as a number ranged 1 to 20.
More important roles (e.g., admins) should be assigned a higher priority.
This feature is crucial for a lot of usecases, such as assigning priority for Commands and Conditionals.

Marked as a diamond in the group editing page, it sets a selected group as default.
When players join the Housing for the first time, or joins without a non-default group, they will be assigned with the new default group.
BE CAREFUL! Deleting a group will reset the default group to the group with the lowest priority.
Marked as a cauldron in the group editing page, it clears all players from the selected group, including offline players.

Customize an item's appearance and behaviour using the Item Editor

The Item Editor allows you to (nearly) fully customize an item's description and behaviour.
To access it, simply run "/item" or "/edititem".
When the command is executed, the Item Editor will open for the item currently held, and it is displayed on the second row of the menu.
There are currently 6 editable item aspects:

items:
Rename Item
	- As the name suggests, it allows you to change the name of the selected item ([Formatting Codes](https://cookiecrood.github.io/html/general/Formatting_Codes.html) can
        be applied)

Edit Lore
	- Change the description of the selected item (Formatting Codes can be applied)

Edit Enchantments
	- Apply or remove any enchantments onto the selected item (levels I~X)

Edit Actions
	- Customize what the selected item does when a player right clicks while holding it

Edit Flags
	- Toggle whether [ enchantments / modifiers (e.g. +7 Attack Damage) / "Unbreakable" / additional ] are
        shown in the description of the selected item

Unbreakable
	- Toggle whether the item's durability can drop

blocks.text: Add some fun or action triggers using Items

Officially called "Items". But to avoid confusion with normal items, they are referred to as "Special Items" in this document.
It can be accessed through Housing Menu (Ghast Tear/Nether Star) > Items (Emerald).

Players with "Item: Mailbox" permission can place down a Mailbox and the owner can right click it to view mails.
The players can right click a Mailbox to obtain a Book and Quill to submit a mail.
(Please note that all signed Books and Quills will go into the Mailbox)

Players with "Item: Egg Hunt" permission can place down Egg Hunt Blocks (hereafter referred as Eggs).
Right clicking one will start an Egg Hunt (repeatable) to locate all the eggs within the House.
There can be at max 25 Eggs in an Egg Hunt. Finding all placed Eggs will end the Egg Hunt and announce the time taken to finish it.

As the name suggests, this item teleports you from one Teleport Pad to the other. Players with "Item: Teleport Pad" permission can place and edit Teleport Pads.
You may choose the "color" of a Teleport Pad, they act as tags to identify them among one another.
Options include: Red, Yellow, Lime, Blue, Magenta, Orange, Gray, White, Green, Aqua, Purple, Black
You may set the destination of a certain Teleport Pad to another with the certain color, "Another House" or "Housing Lobby".
Players with "Item: Launch Pad" permission can place down a Launch Pad and right click it to change its settings.

items: Toggle Mode: Toggles whether stepping on the Launch Pad launches the player "Forward" (4 directions) or "Facing" (all directions)
Change Launch Strength: Set the horizontal launching strength of the Launch Pad (value 1~12, default 5)
Change Vertical Strength: Set the vertical launching strength of the Launch Pad (value 1~12, default 5)

blocks.text:
Taking the appearance of the Light Weighted Pressure Plate, the owner can place a Parkour Block creates a "Parkour Start", "Checkpoint #n" or "Parkour End" of a parkour.
The Parkour Block placed most recently is always the Parkour End. Whenever you place a new one, the previous Parkour End is turned into a Checkpoint.
There can be at max 20 Checkpoints (Not including Start and End) in a House.
(Note: If players that aren't the owner try to place down a Parkour Block, it becomes an ordinary pressure plate)

Players with "Item: Action Pad" permission can place and right click to edit an Action Pad's behaviour.
On default, it takes the appearance of a Heavy Weighted Pressure Plate, but it can also be customized to appear as Light Weighted Pressure Plate, Stone Pressure Plate, or Wooden Pressure Plate.

Players with "Item: Hologram" permission can place and right click to edit a Hologram's content.
It displays text using Name Tags on invisible Armor Stands, and [Formatting Codes](https://cookiecrood.github.io/html/general/Formatting_Codes.html) can be used on a Hologram's text.
It can display at max 5 separate lines.

Players with "Item: NPCs" permission can place and right click while sneaking to edit an NPC.
It is extremely customizable, with its actions when clicked, name, appearance and equipped gear (including held item) being able to be edited.
You may also toggle whether its name tag is hidden, and whether it looks at nearby players.

Players with "Item: Action Button" permission can place and right click while sneaking to edit an Action Button's behaviour.
On default, it takes the appearance of a Stone Button, but it can also be customized to appear as a Wooden Button.
An Action Button behaves exactly the same as an Action Pad, except it is instead in the form of a Button.

Players with "Item: Leaderboard" permission can place and right click to edit a Leaderboard's settings.
It displays the players (and the stat value) that has the highest (or lowest) stat in the House.
Below are its available settings:

Data Provider: Toggles what the Leaderboard displays (Parkour Leaderboard / Player Variable / Team Variable)
Title Override: Customize what is displayed at the top of the Leaderboard, replacing the default
Line Count: Set the amount of players shown on the Leaderboard
Variable: Set the stat displayed on the Leaderboard
Format Type: Set how the numbers are displayed (Number [no commas] / Number (Formatted) [with commas] / Roman Numerals / Duration - Minutes, Seconds / Duration - Days, Hours, Minutes, Seconds)
Invert Sorting: Toggle whether the players with the highest or lowest stat are on top
Show All Entries: Toggle whether players with stat equal to or lower than zero are displayed
Persistent Data: Toggle whether offline players are displayed
Show Personal: Toggle whether the viewing player's stat is displayed at the bottom if they are not within the Leaderboard
Player Conditions: Add filters to which players are displayed
Match Any Conditions: Toggle whether players only have to meet at least 1 Condition to be displayed


Trash Can
Players with "Item: Trash Can" permission can place a Trash Can.
Right clicking a Trash Can opens an inventory with 27 item slots.
Any item thrown into the Trash Can's inventory is deleted after closing the UI (this action is NOT reversible).

Biome Stick
Players with "Item: Biome Stick" permission can use a Biome Stick.
It changes the biome within a custom radius (default 3) to a custom biome (default desert).
Available biomes include: Desert, Forest, Ice Plains, Jungle, Mesa, Ocean, Plains, Swamp, Savanna, Nether, Taiga, Birch Forest, Deep Ocean, Roofed Forest, End, Mushroom Island

Social Blocks
The owner can place down Social Blocks that links to their (or someone else's) social media.
There are currently 5 different social blocks, which are: Twitter, YouTube, Instagram, Twitch, Discord (Server or User)

Miscellaneous Items

Dragon Egg
Banners
	- Unlocked through Collectibles in any Hypixel Lobby
Paintings
	- All vanilla paintings are included, you may now choose the painting you put down instead of it being
	  random

blocks.text: Check out how text would be displayed in a Code Block
Housing Text Scripting Language, created by BusterBrown1218.

HTSL (Housing Text Scripting Language) is both a scripting syntax and a ChatTriggers module designed to help users write, share, and import/export scripts directly within Housing using a macro. Its syntax mirrors Housing code, each line in HTSL corresponds directly to a Housing action, with no additional functionality beyond what Housing already provides.

The creator, BusterBrown1218, describes HTSL as follows:
HTSL is a direct one-to-one, line-to-Housing action script. It is by no means a language, and is only capable of doing what housing does. There is no abstraction, what you write is what you get.
HTSL's purpose is to make it easier for people to develop housings or just sharing code with other people. Having a standard to talk about Housing actions makes it much easier to discuss code as we don't have to use weird different forms of pseudocode unique to everyone.
With Hypixel's latest update to their rules, macros for specifically importing/exporting Housing actions are now allowed, meaning you can safely use HTSL as you want without safe mode enabled.
Before we begin there's a few requirements you need to actually use HTSL:

items: [Forge for 1.8](https://files.minecraftforge.net/net/minecraftforge/forge/index_1.8.9.html)
[ChatTriggers mod for Forge 1.8](https://chattriggers.com/)
[Visual Studio Code (optional, if you want to write code)](https://code.visualstudio.com/Download)
Go to the [HTSL GitHub](https://github.com/BusterBrown1218/HTSL/releases/latest) releases page.
Download the HTSL.zip.
Extract the zipped file into a new folder called HTSL (make sure there is only one HTSL folder, not HTSL\HTSL\rest of files).
Now, in-game we're going to run /ct files, and go into your modules folder and drop your HTSL folder right in there.
Last thing left to do is /ct reload and you can now use the HTSL module!

Create custom commands within the Housing

In every Housing, a set of commands such as /stuck and /clear is introduced to players.
However, you can add new commands to enhance user experience in your Housing.

This feature contains multiple functions, so you can restrict certain commands, toggle command mode and its visibility in chat.
Below are the primary properties about this feature:

There are limited amount of custom commands you can create in your Housing.
Without Housing+: 10 CommandsWith Housing+: 50 Commands

Command Mode
Command Mode has 2 options: Self and Targeted.
If the command is in Self mode, the command will execute on the player using the command when performed.
If the command is in Targeted mode, the command must include a target player as an argument, and runs on the target player when performed.

Required Group Priority
This function restricts a selected command so only players in a group with a required group priority can perform the command.
To learn more about Group Priority, head to Permissions and Groups page.

Command Listed
This function toggles whether a selected command should be listed to players in the commands auto-completion tab.
The command will only be listed to players in a group with a required group priority.

How to edit my custom commands?
To edit your custom commands, head into your Housing, and type in "/commands".
To add a custom command, click on Create Command (Marked as a paper)
To edit the actions in a command, left click on the selected command.
To edit the properties of a command, right click on the selected command.
To remove a command, right click on the selected command, then select Delete Command (Marked as a TNT).

Command Mode has 2 options: Self and Targeted.
If the command is in Self mode, the command will execute on the player using the command when performed.
If the command is in Targeted mode, the command must include a target player as an argument, and runs on the target player when performed.

This function restricts a selected command so only players in a group with a required group priority can perform the command.
To learn more about Group Priority, head to [Permissions and Groups](https://cookiecrood.github.io/html/general/Groups_and_Permissions.html) page.

This function toggles whether a selected command should be listed to players in the commands auto-completion tab.
The command will only be listed to players in a group with a required group priority.
How to edit my custom commands?

To edit your custom commands, head into your Housing, and type in "/commands".
To add a custom command, click on Create Command (Marked as a paper)
To edit the actions in a command, left click on the selected command.
To edit the properties of a command, right click on the selected command.
To remove a command, right click on the selected command, then select Delete Command (Marked as a TNT).
Power all your imaginations with Interactives

Edit Actions allow Housing owners to customize interactions with clickable items, NPCs, and regions.
Using this feature, you can set commands, messages, or triggers when players interact with specific objects—enhancing gameplay, roleplay, or minigame mechanics.

Key Features:

Item Actions – Run commands or send messages when players click items.
NPC Interactions – Customize dialogue, teleports, or permissions when talking to NPCs.
Region Triggers – Execute actions when players enter/exit designated areas.


This system provides deeper control over your Housing experience, making builds more dynamic and interactive.
When will we use Edit Actions?
Edit Actions is used everywhere around Housing Coding: Region Execution, Event Actions, Commands, Functions, Click Action in Custom Menus, Action Buttons // Pads // NPCs.
Marked as a cauldron in an action editor, it restores the action you last removed.
How to add // edit // remove actions?

To add an action, head into the action editor, and click Add Action (Marked as paper).
To edit an action, left click on the selected action. Press and hold SHIFT, then left/right click to change its order.
To remove an action, right click on the selected action.
Edit Actions currently contain 36 main functions (excluding Conditionals). Below is each component explained in detail:

Marked with: Player Head
Changes the group of a target player.
It contains 2 settings: Target Group and Demotion Protection.
Group: When the action is executed, the target player's group is set to the set target group.
Demotion Protection: When enabled, the target player's group WILL NOT be changed when the target group has a lower group priority than that of the player's original group.
To learn more about Group Priorities, head to [Permissions and Groups](https://cookiecrood.github.io/html/general/Groups_and_Permissions.html) page.

Marked with: Iron Bars
Kills the target player.
This action will NOT work when the target player is in Creative Mode!!!

Marked with: Golden Apple
Heals the target player back to full health.

Marked with: Book
Displays a title to the target player on the middle of their screen.
It contains 5 settings: Title, Subtitle, Fadein, Stay, and Fadeout
Title: Displayed as the primary text on the screen.
Subtitle: Displayed as the secondary text on the screen, below Title.
Fadein: Counted in seconds, determines how much time it takes for the title to gradually appear.
Stay: Counted in seconds, determines how long the title should stay on screen.
Fadeout: Counted in seconds, determines how much time it takes for the title to gradually disappear.

Marked with: Book and Quill
Displays a message to the target player at a position above the player's hotbar.

Marked with: Stone
Resets a player's inventory.
If a default inventory layout is set, the player's inventory will be reset to the default inventory layout.

Marked with: Dandelion
TChanges a player's maximum health.
It contains 3 settings: Max Health, Mode, and Heal On Change.
Max Health: Specifies a set variable. (Default: 20)
Mode: Specifies which algorithmic action to perform on the variable. (Set, Increment, Decrement, Multiply, Divide)
Heal on Change: When the maximum health of the player is changed, heal the target player to full health.

Marked with: Lightweighted Pressure Plate (Gold)
If a parkour is present in the Housing, teleports the player to the last parkour checkpoint they reached.
If the target player hasn't started a parkour, teleports the player to the parkour start plate.

Marked with: Chest
Gives the target player a selected item.
It contains 4 settings: Item, Allow Multiple, Inventory Slot, and Replace Existing Item.
Item: Specifies the selected item given to the player. Stacking items in the variable will give the player that amount.
Allow Multiple: When disabled, if the target player already has the target item, it won't be given again.
Inventory Slot: Specifies where the item appears in the target player's inventory. It can be any inventory slot.
Replace Existing Item: When enabled, if an item currently occupies the inventory slot it will be replaced with the new item.

Marked with: Cauldron
Removes a selected item from the targeted player. Stacking items in the variable will remove that amount from the player.
If the player has insufficient amount of items, it will be fully cleared.

Marked with: Empty Map
Sends a message in chat to the target player.

Marked with: Water Bottle
Applies a potion effect to the targeted player.
It contains 5 settings: Effect, Duration, Level, Override Existing Effects, and Show Potion Icon.
Effect: Determines the potion effect the target player would get.
Duration: Counted in seconds, determines the longevity of the potion effect. (Maximum: 2592000)
Level: Specifies ntensity of the effect. (Maximum: 10)
Override Existing Effects: When enabled, replaces the current potion effect if the target player already has the selected potion effect.
Show Potion Icon: When enabled, shows the potion icon on the top right of the Minecraft Client for players running version 1.9 or later.

Marked with: Empty Bottle
Clears all potion effects of the targeted player.

Marked with: Experience Bottles
Adds XP levels to the target player.

Marked with: Bookshelf
Sends a player to any selected lobby in Hypixel.
Due to Owner Protection, Housing owners will not be affected by this action.

Marked with: Feather
Changes a variable stat of the targeted player. It can be a number or a string.
It contains 5 settings: Holder, Variable, Mode, Value, and Automatic Unset.
Holder: Specifies which type of variable will be changed. (Player, Global, Team)
Variable: Specifies the name of the target variable.
Mode: Specifies which algorithmic action to perform on the variable. (Unset, Set, Increment, Decrement, Multiply, Divide)
Value: Specifies the value to be assigned to the variable.
Automatic Unset: When enabled, values that are considered default will unset the variable automatically.

Marked with: Ender Pearl
Teleports the target player to a set location.
It contains 2 settings: Location and Prevent Teleporting Inside Blocks.
Location: Specifies the location the target player gets teleported to.
Options include: House Spawn Location, Location of the player activating the function, Location of the coder of the function, and Custom Coordinates.
Prevent Teleporting Inside Blocks: If the target coordinate is within a block, the target player automatically gets teleported upwards until there's sufficient space.

Marked with: Lightweighted Pressure Plate (Gold)
Ends the target player's timed parkour session. (IF applicable)
A reason for ending the session can also be provided to the target player.

Marked with: Note Block
Gives the target player a selected item.
It contains 4 settings: Sound, Volume, Pitch, and Location.
Sound: Specifies the sound to be played. Must be a vanilla Minecraft sound.
Volume: (Range: 0-2), determines the volume of the sound.
Pitch: (Range 0-2), determines the pitch of the sound.
Location: Specifies where would the sound be played.

Marked with: Compass
Specifies where would the compass of a target player point towards. Input must be a coordinate.

Marked with: Daylight Detector
Specifies what gamemode will the target player obtain. (Adventure // Survival // Creative)

Marked with: Red Apple
Specifies the amount of health the target player gets.
It contains 2 settings: Health and Mode.
Health: Specifies a specific variable. (Default: 20).
Mode: Specifies which algorithmic action to perform on the variable. (Set, Increment, Decrement, Multiply, Divide)

Marked with: Cooked Steak
Specifies the amount of hunger/saturation level the target player gets.
It contains 2 settings: Level and Mode.
Level: Specifies a specific variable. (Default: 20).
Mode: Specifies which algorithmic action to perform on the variable. (Set, Increment, Decrement, Multiply, Divide)

Marked with: Ender Chest
Executes a single random action from a list of selected actions.
Every Edit Action is allowed to be randomized within except Conditionals.

Marked with: Activator Rail
Triggers a pre-defined function. (/functions)

Marked with: Iron Axe
Applies a pre-defined inventory layout to the target player.

Marked with: Enchanted Book
Enchants the item held by the target player.
It contains 2 settings: Enchantment and Level.
Level: Specifies a target enchantment. All enchantments from Minecraft 1.8 are included.
Mode: Specifies the intensity of the enchantment. (Range: 1-10)

Marked with: Red Bed
Pauses execution for the remaining actions for a specific amount of time. (Counted in ticks, 20 ticks = 1 second)

Marked with: Wooden Sign
Allocates the target player to a team.

Marked with: Chest
Displays a custom menu to the target player.

Marked with: Dropper
Drops an item at a specific location.
It contains 6 settings: Item, Location, Drop Naturally, Disable Item Merging, Prioritize Player, and Fallback to Inventory.
Item: Specifies a target item / block.
Location: Specifies a target location for the item to appear.
Drop Naturally: When enabled, the item will be dropped naturally in the Housing, having slight randomness to its location.
Disable Item Merging: When enabled, the item will not merge with other items on the ground.
Prioritize Player: When enabled, the player the action is executed on will be prioritized for picking up the item.
Fallback to Inventory: When enabled, items will be put into the player inventory if they can't be dropped in the Housing.

Marked with: Slime Block
Changes the velocity direction of the player.
It contains 3 settings: X Velocity, Y Velocity, and Z Velocity.
Each direction and velocity value should be determined using the coordinates system (F3)

Marked with: Slime Ball
Launches the player in the general direction of the provided location.
It ontains 2 settings: Target Location and Launch Strength.
Target Location: Specifies the target location.
Demotion Protection: Specifies the strength of launching the target player.

Marked with: Water Bucket
Changes the weather for a target player. This will result in the weather being different from the world while set. (Sunny // Raining)

Marked with: Clock
Changes the time of the world for a target player.

Marked with: Water Bucket
Toggles whether the player's nametag is shown or hidden to other players in the Housing. (On // Off)

Marked with: Redstone Dust
(IF-THEN-ELSE) Use conditions to only execute provided actions when conditions are met by the player.
It contains 4 settings: Conditions, Match Any Condition, If Actions, and Else Actions.
Conditions: Specifies the selected item given to the player. Stacking items in the variable will give the player that amount.
Match Any Condition: When enabled, only one condition needs to match for IF ACTIONS to be performed.
If Actions: Actions that will run when the conditions are met.
Else Actions: Actions that will run if the conditions are not met.
Each condition has an invert option, which changes the condition to activate when the condition is not met.
Here is a list of all Conditionals:

Trigger an action when entering/exiting an area using Regions

When a player enters or leaves a "Region", a customizable effect is triggered.
                The Regions menu can be accessed through:

items: "/region" OR "/regions"
Housing Menu (Nether Star/Ghast Tear) > "Systems" (Activator Rail) > "Regions" (Grass Block)
Run "//", "//wand" OR "/wand" to get the "Region Selection Tool".
Use the tool to select position A (left click a block) and position B (right click a block).
Open the Regions menu and click on "Create a Region" and name the Region.

blocks.text: Congratulations! You've created a Region. You can now customize its actions when a player enters/exit the Region.

items:
"Rename Region" (Name Tag)  
        – Set the Region’s name after the first time you named it

"Teleport Region" (Ender Pearl)  
        – Teleport to the northwestern corner of the Region

"Move Region" (Stick)  
        – Move the Region to your current Region Selection Tool area

"PvP Settings" (Iron Sword)  
        – Toggle damage and PvP settings (e.g. Fall Damage, Keep Inventory)

"Entry Actions" (Paper)  
        – Set actions triggered when a player enters the Region

"Exit Actions" (Paper)  
        – Set actions triggered when a player leaves the Region

"Delete Region" (TNT)  
        – Delete the Region after confirmation

blocks.text: Design Scoreboard aesthetics using Scoreboard Editor

In every Housing, a scoreboard is shown on the right side of your screen.
Often it displays the Housing's name, the amount of guests, and the amount of cookies recieved.
However, you can redesign it and customize it to your own liking, including: adding or removing information.
Be aware! Due to limitations, the Scoreboard can only hold up to 10 items!

To edit your scoreboard, head into your Housing, and type in "/scoreboard".
To add a scoreboard item, click on Add Scoreboard Item (Marked as a paper)
To remove a scoreboard item, right click on the selected scoreboard item.
To change the order of the scoreboard items, press and hold shift, while left / right clicking any scoreboard item.
